Our\n            history dates back to 1909, when American Building Maintenance Company began as a window washing company in\n            San Francisco with one employee. In 1985, we were incorporated in Delaware under the name American Building\n            Maintenance Industries, Inc., as the successor to the business originally founded in 1909. In 1994, we\n            changed our name to ABM Industries Incorporated. A majority of our revenue is derived\n            from services that require competitive bids. The low cost of entry in the facility services business results\n            in a very competitive market. We compete mainly with regional and local owner-operated companies that may\n            have more acute vision into local markets and significantly lower labor and overhead costs, providing them\n            with a competitive advantage in those regards. We also compete indirectly with companies that can perform\n            for themselves one or more of the services we provide. Compliance\n            with this rapidly expanding area of law will require significant management and financial resources, and we\n            could be subjected to additional legal risk or financial losses if we are not in compliance. We incur risks relating to our employment of these workers, including but not limited to: claims\n            by our employees of discrimination, harassment, violations of wage and hour requirements, or violations of\n            other federal, state, or local laws; claims of misconduct or negligence on the part of our employees; and\n            claims related to the employment of unlicensed personnel. We also incur risks and claims related to the\n            imposition on our employees of policies or practices of our clients that may be different from our own. Some\n            or all of these claims may lead to litigation, including class action litigation, and these matters may\n            cause us to incur negative publicity with respect to alleged claims. Additionally, there are risks to all\n            employers in some states, such as California, resulting from new and unanticipated judicial interpretations\n            of existing laws and the application of those new interpretations against employers on a retroactive basis.\n            It is not possible to predict the outcome of these lawsuits or any other proceeding, and our insurance may\n            not cover all claims that may be asserted against us. These lawsuits and other proceedings may consume\n            substantial amounts of our financial and managerial resources. An unfavorable outcome with respect to\n            current lawsuits, including the'}, {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Bucio'}, {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'case\n            described in Note 13, “Commitments and Contingencies,” in the Notes to consolidated financial\n            statements (included in Part II., Item 8 of this Form 10-K), and any future lawsuits may, individually or in\n            the aggregate, cause us to incur substantial liabilities that could have a material adverse effect upon our\n            business, reputation, financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows.'}]}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'A\n            significant number of our employees are covered by collective bargaining agreements that could expose us to\n            potential liabilities in relation to our participation in multiemployer pension plans, requirements to make\n            contributions to other benefit plans, and the potential for strikes, work slowdowns or similar activities,\n            and union organizing drives.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n            participate in various multiemployer pension plans that provide defined pension benefits to employees\n            covered by collective bargaining agreements. Because of the nature of multiemployer pension plans, there are\n            risks to us associated with participation in these plans that differ from single-employer plans. Assets\n            contributed by an employer to a multiemployer pension plan are not segregated into a separate account and\n            are not restricted to provide benefits only to employees of that contributing employer. In the event another\n            participating employer in a multiemployer pension plan no longer contributes to the plan, the unfunded\n            obligations of the plan may be borne by the remaining participating employers, including us. In the event of\n            the termination of a multiemployer pension plan or a complete or partial withdrawal from a multiemployer\n            pension plan, under applicable law we could incur material withdrawal liabilities. We further discuss our\n            participation in multiemployer pension and postretirement plans in Note 12, “Employee Benefit\n            Plans,” in the Notes to consolidated financial statements. In addition, the terms of collective\n            bargaining agreements require us to contribute to various fringe benefit plans, including health and\n            welfare, pension, and training plans, all of which require us to have appropriate systems in place to assure\n            timely and accurate payment of contributions. The failure to make timely and accurate contributions as a\n            result of a systems failure could have a negative impact on our financial position.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': [{'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'At\n            October\xa031, 2020, approximatel'}, {'@style': ""background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'y\n            32% o'}, {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'f our\n            employees were subject to various local collective bargaining agreements, some of which will expire or\n            become subject to renegotiation during 2021. We compute our income tax provision based on enacted tax rates\n            in the jurisdictions in which we operate. As tax rates vary among taxing jurisdictions, a change in earnings\n            attributable to the various jurisdictions in which we operate could result in an unfavorable change in our\n            overall tax provision. Additionally, at any point in time, we may be under examination for income-based,\n            sales-based, payroll, or other non-income taxes. We regularly assess the likelihood of adverse outcomes\n            resulting from these audits to determine the adequacy of our provision for income taxes. We may recognize\n            additional tax expense, be subject to additional tax liabilities, or incur losses and penalties due to\n            adverse outcomes in tax audits or changes in laws, regulations, administrative practices, principles,\n            assessments by authorities, and interpretations related to tax laws, including tax rules in various\n            jurisdictions, which could have an adverse effect on our operating results and financial condition.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Risks\n            Relating to Market and Economic Conditions'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Changes\n            in general economic conditions, such as changes in energy prices, government regulations, or consumer\n            preferences, could reduce the demand for facility services and, as a result, reduce our earnings and\n            adversely affect our financial condition.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'In\n            certain geographic areas and service lines, our most profitable revenues are related to supplemental\n            services requested by clients outside of the standard service specification (“work orders”).\n            This contract type is commonly used in janitorial services and includes cleanup after tenant moves,\n            construction cleanup, flood cleanup, and snow removal. A continuing decline in occupancy rates could result\n            in a decline in scope of work, including work orders, and depressed prices for our services. Slow domestic\n            and international economic growth or other negative changes in global, national, and local economic\n            conditions could have a negative impact on our business. Specifically, adverse economic conditions may\n            result in clients cutting back on discretionary spending. Additionally, since a significant portion of our\n            aviation services and parking revenues are tied to the volume of airline passengers, hotel guests, and\n            sports arena attendees, results for these businesses could be adversely affected by continued curtailment of\n            business, personal travel, or discretionary spending. The use of ride sharing services and car sharing\n            services may also lead to a decline in parking demand at airports and in urban areas.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Energy\n            efficiency projects are designed to reduce a client’s overall consumption of commodities, such as\n            electricity and natural gas.\xa0As such, downward fluctuations in commodity prices may reduce client\n            demand for those projects. We also depend, in part, on federal and state legislation and policies that\n            support energy efficiency projects. If current legislation or policies are amended, eliminated, or not\n            extended beyond their current expiration dates, or if funding for energy incentives is reduced or delayed,\n            it could also adversely affect our ability to obtain new business. In some instances, we offer certain of\n            these clients guaranteed energy savings on installed equipment. In the event those guaranteed savings are\n            not achieved, we may be required to pay liquidated or other damages. All of these factors could have an\n            adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Risks\n            Relating to Financial Matters'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Future\n            increases in the level of our borrowings or in interest rates could affect our results of operations.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Although\n            we have paid down portions of our indebtedness under our syndicated secured credit facility, our future\n            ability to make payments on our debt, fund our other liquidity needs, and make planned capital expenditures\n            will depend on our ability to generate cash. We cannot\n            guarantee that our business will generate sufficient cash flow from our operations or that future borrowings\n            will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to make payments on our debt, fund other\n            liquidity needs, make planned capital expenditures, or continue our dividend.'}}, {'@style': 'height:42.75pt;position:relative;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'bottom:0;position:absolute;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:center', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': '13'}}}}, {'@style': 'min-height:42.75pt;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt', 'span': {'br': None}}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n            degree to which we are leveraged could have important consequences for shareholders. For example, being\n            highly leveraged could: require us to dedicate a substantial portion of our cash flows from operations to\n            the payment of debt service, reducing the availability of our cash flow to fund working capital, share\n            repurchases, capital expenditures, acquisitions, and other general corporate purposes; limit our\n            availability to obtain additional financing in the future to enable us to react to changes in our business;\n            and place us at a competitive disadvantage compared to businesses in our industry that have less\n            debt.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Additionally,\n            any future increase in the level of our indebtedness will likely increase our interest expense, which could\n            negatively impact our profitability. Current interest rates on borrowings under our credit facility are\n            variable and include the use of the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”). In 2017, the U.K.\n            Financial Conduct Authority announced that it intends to phase out LIBOR by the end of 2021. In addition,\n            other regulators have suggested reforming or replacing other benchmark rates. The discontinuation, reform,\n            or replacement of LIBOR or any other benchmark rates may result in fluctuating interest rates that may have\n            a negative impact on our interest expense and our profitability.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Further,\n            our credit facility contains both financial covenants and other covenants that limit our ability to engage\n            in specific transactions. Any failure to comply with covenants in the credit facility could result in an\n            event of default that, if not cured or waived, would have a material adverse effect on us.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Impairment\n            of goodwill and long-lived assets could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and\n            results of operations.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n            evaluate goodwill for impairment annually, in the fourth quarter, or more often if impairment indicators\n            exist. We also review long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate\n            that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. If the fair value of one of our reporting\n            units is less than its carrying value, or if as a result of a recoverability test we conclude that the\n            projected undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying amount, we would record an impairment charge\n            related to goodwill or long-lived assets, respectively. (For example, during the second quarter of 2020,\n            given the general deterioration in economic and market conditions arising from the Pandemic, we identified a\n            triggering event that resulted in the impairment of goodwill and intangible assets.) The assumptions used to\n            determine impairment require significant judgment, and the amount of the impairment could have a material\n            adverse effect on our reported financial results for the period in which the charge is taken.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'If\n            we fail to maintain proper and effective internal control over financial reporting in the future, our\n            ability to produce accurate and timely financial statements could be negatively impacted, which could harm\n            our operating results and investor perceptions of our Company and as a result may have a material adverse\n            effect on the value of our common stock.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Pursuant\n            to Section 404 of the Sarbanes Oxley Act of 2002 and related rules, our management is required to report on,\n            and our independent registered public accounting firm is required to attest to, the effectiveness of our\n            internal control over financial reporting. The rules governing the standards that must be met for management\n            to assess our internal control over financial reporting are complex and require significant documentation,\n            testing, and, in some instances, remediation. We have acquired entities that had no publicly traded debt or\n            equity and therefore were not previously required to conform to the rules and regulations of the SEC,\n            especially related to their internal control structure. When we acquire such entities, they may not have in\n            place all the necessary controls as required by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. Integrating\n            acquired entities into our internal control over financial reporting has required and will continue to\n            require significant time and resources from our management and other personnel, which increases our\n            compliance costs. We are required to include our assessment of the effectiveness of the internal controls\n            over financial reporting of entities we acquire in our overall assessment, so we must plan to complete the\n            evaluation and integration of internal controls over financial reporting and report our assessment within\n            the required time frame.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'In\n            addition, with the increasing frequency of cyber-related frauds perpetrated to obtain inappropriate\n            payments, we need to ensure our internal controls related to authorizing the transfer of funds and changing\n            our vendor master files are adequate. Furthermore, the introduction of new, and changes to existing,\n            enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) and financial reporting information systems create\n            implementation and change management risks that require effective internal controls to mitigate. Failure to\n            maintain an effective internal control environment could have a material adverse effect on our ability to\n            accurately report our financial results, the market’s perception of our business, and our stock\n            price.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'br': None}}, {'@style': 'height:42.75pt;position:relative;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'bottom:0;position:absolute;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:center', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': '14'}}}}, {'@style': 'min-height:42.75pt;width:100%', 'div': {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt', 'span': {'br': None}}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'General\n            Risk Factors'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Our\n            business may be negatively impacted by adverse weather conditions.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Weather\n            conditions such as snow storms, heavy flooding, hurricanes, and fluctuations in temperatures can negatively\n            impact portions of our business. This could include\n            disruptions due to disasters, pandemics, weather-related or similar events (such as fires, hurricanes,\n            blizzards, earthquakes, and floods), political instability, labor strikes, or war (including acts of\n            terrorism or hostilities) that could impact our markets. If a disruption occurs in one location and persons\n            in that location are unable to communicate with or travel to or work from other locations, our ability to\n            service and interact with our clients and others may suffer, and we may not be able to successfully\n            implement contingency plans that depend on communications or travel. These events may increase the\n            volatility of financial results due to unforeseen costs with partial or no corresponding compensation from\n            clients. There also can be no assurance that the disaster recovery and crisis management procedures we\n            employ will suffice in any particular situation to avoid a significant loss. We have also actively managed direct labor and related personnel costs,\n            including: imposing furloughs or reduced hours for certain service employees in markets significantly\n            impacted by business slowdowns and shutdowns; reducing our planned capital and operating expenditures and\n            management of other expenses; and suspending share repurchases under our share repurchase program. These\n            financial covenants were effective with the quarter ended April 30, 2020. The anti-cash hoarding provision and certain\n            of these restrictions were terminated from the Credit Facility in the fourth quarter of 2020 due to our\n            favorable cash flow position and leverage ratios. intangible assets for impairment whenever events\n                            or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be\n                            recoverable. Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit\n                            level, which represents an operating segment or a component of an operating segment.\n                            Goodwill is tested for impairment by either performing a qualitative evaluation or a\n                            quantitative test. The qualitative evaluation is an assessment of factors to determine\n                            whether it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its\n                            carrying amount, including goodwill. We may elect not to perform the qualitative assessment\n                            for some or all of our reporting units and instead perform a quantitative impairment test.'}}, {'span': {'br': None}}, {'span': {'br': None}}]}, {'@colspan': '3', '@style': 'padding:0 1pt'}, {'@colspan': '3', '@style': 'border-top:1pt solid #000000;padding:2px 1pt;text-align:left;vertical-align:top', 'div': [{'span': {'br': None}}, {'span': {'br': None}}, {'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:9pt;font-weight:400;line-height:100%"", '#text': 'Our\n                            impairment evaluations require us to apply judgment in determining whether a triggering\n                            event has occurred, including the evaluation of whether it is more- likely-than-not that a\n                            long-lived asset will be disposed of significantly before the end of its previously\n                            estimated useful life. Incorrect estimation of useful lives may result in inaccurate\n                            depreciation and amortization charges over future periods leading to future impairment.'}}, {'span': {'br': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:9pt;font-weight:400;line-height:100%"", '#text': 'During\n                            the second quarter of 2020, given the general deterioration in economic and market\n                            conditions arising from the Pandemic, we identified a triggering event indicating possible\n                            impairment of goodwill and intangible assets. For the three goodwill reporting units tested\n                            quantitatively, we estimated the fair value using a weighting of fair values derived from an\n                            income approach and a market approach. Based on the evaluation performed, we determined that\n                            goodwill was impaired for each of the three goodwill reporting units evaluated and\n                            recognized a non-cash impairment charge totaling $163.8 million ($99.3 million related to\n                            Education, $55.5 million related to Aviation, and $9.0 million related to our U.K. Technical\n                            Solutions business). We also recognized intangible asset impairment charges of $5.6 million\n                            related to Aviation and $3.4 million related to our U.K. Technical Solutions business. We\n                            performed our annual goodwill impairment analysis on August 1, 2020 using a qualitative\n                            approach since there were no indicators of impairment subsequent to our quantitative\n                            analysis performed in the second quarter of 2020 as discussed above. As a result of the\n                            qualitative analysis, we concluded that there were no further impairments.'}}, {'span': {'br': None}}, {'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:9pt;font-weight:400;line-height:100%"", '#text': 'During\n                            the third quarter of 2019, in connection with the reorganization of our Healthcare business,\n                            a goodwill impairment analysis was performed on the underlying reporting unit immediately\n                            before the reorganization, and we concluded that the estimated fair value of the underlying\n                            reporting unit substantially exceeded its carrying value immediately before the\n                            reorganization and that no further evaluation of impairment was necessary. Additionally, we\n                            performed our annual goodwill impairment analysis on August 1, 2019, and concluded that the\n                            implied fair value of each of our reporting units was substantially in excess of its\n                            carrying value and that no further evaluation of impairment was necessary. 2016-13, issued in June 2016, replaces the existing guidance surrounding measurement and\n                        recognition of credit losses on financial assets measured at amortized cost, including trade\n                        receivables and investments in certain debt securities, by requiring recognition of an allowance\n                        for credit losses expected to be incurred over an asset’s life based on relevant\n                        information about past events, current conditions, and supportable forecasts impacting its\n                        ultimate collectibility. This “expected loss” model will result in earlier\n                        recognition of credit losses than the current “as incurred” model, under which\n                        losses are recognized only upon occurrence of an event that gives rise to the incurrence of a\n                        probable loss. ASU 2018-19 was issued in November 2018 and clarifies that\n                        receivables arising from operating leases are should be accounted for in accordance with Topic\n                        842, Leases.ASU 2019-11 was issued in November 2019 to clarify, improve, and amend\n                        certain aspects of ASU 2016-13, such as disclosures related to accrued interest receivables and\n                        the estimation of credit losses associated with financial assets secured by\n                        collateral.ASU 2019-05 was issued in May 2019 to provide targeted transition relief\n                        allowing entities to make an irrevocable one-time election upon adoption of the new credit\n                        losses standard to measure financial assets previously measured at amortized cost (except\n                        held-to-maturity securities) using the fair value option.We do not expect adoption\n                        to 'margin-bottom:9pt;margin-top:9pt;text-align:center', 'span': {'br': None}}, {'@id': 'ifefa58cec8564209b9c0a3ca41dbda61_82'}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'ITEM\xa07A.\n            QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We have\n            market risk exposure related to interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates. Market risk is measured\n            as the potential negative impact on earnings, cash flows, or fair values resulting from a hypothetical\n            change in interest rates or foreign currency exchange rates.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Interest\n            Rate Risk'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We are\n            primarily exposed to interest rate risk through our variable rate borrowings under our Credit Facility. At\n            October\xa031, 2020, we had total outstanding borrowings of $725.3 million. To limit exposure to upward\n            movements in interest rates, we entered into interest rate swap agreements to fix the interest rates on a\n            substantial portion of our outstanding borrowings. At October\xa031, 2020, we had interest rate swaps with\n            an underlying notional amount of $440.0 million and fixed interest rates of 2.83%, 2.84%, and 2.86%. On May\n            28, 2020, we amended our Credit Facility to further enhance our financial flexibility as a precautionary\n            measure in response to uncertainty arising from the Pandemic. The Amendment changed the interest rate,\n            interest margins, and commitment fees applicable to loans and commitments under the Credit Facility. The new\n            interest rate includes an interest rate floor of 0.75% to the Eurocurrency rate on the revolving loans.\n            Based on our average borrowings, interest rates, interest rate floor, and interest rate swaps in effect at\n            October\xa031, 2020, a 100 basis point increase in LIBOR would decrease our future earnings and cash flows\n            by $2.5 million. For 2019, our market risk exposure related to interest rate fluctuations was $4.3 million.\n            As actual interest rate movements over time are uncertain, our interest rate swaps pose potential interest\n            rate risks if interest rates decrease. As of October\xa031, 2020, the fair value of our interest rate swap\n            agreements was a liability of $15.5 million.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Foreign\n            Currency Exchange Rate Risk'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We are\n            primarily exposed to the impact of foreign exchange rate risk through our U.K. operations where the\n            functional currency is the GBP. As we intend to remain permanently invested in these foreign operations, we\n            do not utilize hedging instruments to mitigate foreign currency exchange risks. If we change our intent with\n            respect to such international investment, we would expect to implement strategies designed to manage those\n            risks in an effort to mitigate the Those standards require that we plan and\n            perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial\n            reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audit of internal control over financial reporting\n            included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a\n            material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal\n            control based on the assessed risk. Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we\n            considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our\n            opinion.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-bottom:10pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Definition\n            and Limitations of Internal Control Over Financial Reporting'}}, {'@style': 'margin-bottom:10pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'A\n            company’s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable\n            assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for\n            external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company’s internal\n            control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1)\xa0pertain to the\n            maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and\n            dispositions of the assets of the company; (2)\xa0provide reasonable assurance that transactions are\n            recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted\n            accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance\n            with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3)\xa0provide reasonable assurance\n            regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the\n            company’s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-bottom:10pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Because\n            of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect\n            misstatements. Right-of-use (“ROU”) assets and lease liabilities are\n                    recognized based on the present value of lease payments over the lease term with lease expense\n                    recognized on a straight-line basis. We use our incremental borrowing rate to determine the present\n                    value of future lease payments unless the implicit rate in a lease is readily determinable. Our\n                    incremental borrowing rate is the rate of interest we would have to pay to borrow on a\n                    collateralized basis over a similar term at an amount equal to the lease payments in a similar\n                    economic environment. This incremental borrowing rate is applied to the minimum lease payments\n                    within each lease agreement to determine the amounts of our ROU assets and lease liabilities. We amortize\n                    other non-customer acquired intangibles using a straight-line method of amortization. We evaluate\n                    other intangible assets, as well as our long-lived assets, for impairment whenever events or changes\n                    in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. When this\n                    occurs, a recoverability test is performed that compares the projected undiscounted cash flows from\n                    the use and eventual disposition of an asset or asset group to its carrying amount.\xa0If the\n                    projected undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying amount, we calculate an impairment\n                    loss. In the absence of active markets for\n                    identical assets or liabilities, such measurements involve developing assumptions based on market\n                    observable data and, in the absence of such data, internal information that is consistent with what\n                    market participants would use in a hypothetical transaction that occurs at the measurement date.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Observable\n                    inputs reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs reflect our\n                    market assumptions. Once a contract is identified, we evaluate whether it\n                    is a combined or single contract and whether it should be accounted for as more than one performance\n                    obligation. Generally, most of our contracts are cancelable by either party without a substantive\n                    penalty, and the majority of our contracts have a notification period of 30 to 60 days. {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n                    majority of our contracts contain multiple promises that represent an integrated bundle of services\n                    comprised of activities that may vary over time; however, these activities fulfill a single\n                    integrated performance obligation since we perform a continuous service that is substantially the\n                    same and has the same pattern of transfer to the customer. Our performance obligations are primarily\n                    satisfied over time as we provide the related services. We do not estimate the variable consideration for these arrangements;\n                    rather, we recognize these variable fees in the period they are earned. Some of our contracts, often\n                    related to Airline Services, may also include performance incentives based on variable performance\n                    measures that are ascertained exclusively by future performance and therefore cannot be estimated at\n                    contract inception and are recognized as revenue once known and mutually agreed upon. We include\n                    estimated amounts in the transaction price to the extent it is probable that a significant reversal\n                    of cumulative revenue recognized will not occur when the uncertainty associated with the variable\n                    consideration is resolved. Our estimates of variable consideration and determination of whether to\n                    include estimated amounts in the transaction price are based largely on an assessment of our\n                    anticipated performance and all information (historical, current, and forecasted) that is reasonably\n                    available to us.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n                    primarily account for our performance obligations under the series guidance, using the as-invoiced\n                    practical expedient when applicable. We consider\n                    contract modifications to exist when the modification either changes the consideration, creates new\n                    performance obligations, or changes the existing scope of the contract and related performance\n                    obligations. We measure progress toward satisfaction of the performance\n                    obligation as the services are provided, and revenue is recognized at the agreed-upon contractual\n                    amount over time because the customer simultaneously receives and consumes the benefits of the\n                    services as they are performed.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Square-Foot'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Square-foot\n                    arrangements are contracts in which the client agrees to pay a fixed fee every month based on the\n                    actual square footage serviced over a specified contract term. This measurement and comparison process requires updates to the estimate of total\n                    costs to complete the contract, and these updates may include subjective assessments and judgments.\n                    Equipment purchased for these projects is project-specific and considered a value-added element to\n                    our work. Equipment costs are incurred when title is transferred to us, typically upon delivery to\n                    the work site. Revenue for uninstalled equipment is recognized at cost and the associated margin is\n                    deferred until installation is substantially complete. Prior to November 1, 2018, we recognized\n                    revenue and margin on uninstalled equipment consistent with other project costs under the\n                    percentage-of-completion method.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n                    recognize revenue over time for all of our services as we perform them, because (i) control\n                    continuously transfers to the customer as work progresses or (ii) we have the right to bill the\n                    customer as costs are incurred. The customer typically controls the work in process as evidenced\n                    either by contractual termination clauses or by our rights to payment for work performed to date\n                    plus a reasonable profit to deliver products or services that do not have an alternative use to\n                    us.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Certain\n                    project contracts include a schedule of billings or invoices to the customer based on our\n                    job-to-date percentage of completion of specific tasks inherent in the fulfillment of our\n                    performance obligation(s) or in accordance with a fixed billing schedule. Fixed billing schedules\n                    may not precisely match the actual costs incurred. Therefore, revenue recognized may differ from\n                    amounts that can be billed or invoiced to the customer at any point during the contract, resulting\n                    in balances that are considered revenue recognized in excess of cumulative billings or cumulative\n                    billings in excess of revenue recognized. Advanced payments from our customers generally do not\n                    represent a significant financing component as the payments are used to meet working capital demands\n                    that can be higher in the early stages of a contract, as well as to protect us from our customer\n                    failing to meet its obligations under the contract.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Certain\n                    projects include service maintenance agreements under which existing systems are repaired and\n                    maintained for a specific period of time. Our service maintenance agreements are generally one-year renewable agreements.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#0046ad;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Franchise'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n                    franchise certain engineering services through individual and area franchises under the Linc Service\n                    and TEGG brands, which are part of ABM Technical Solutions. Prior to November 1, 2018, initial fees from sales of franchise licenses were\n                    recognized in the year of sale.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Royalty\n                    fee revenue consists of sales-based royalties received as part of the consideration for the\n                    franchise right, which is calculated as a percentage of the franchisees’ revenue. We recognize\n                    royalty fee revenue at the agreed-upon contractual rates over time as the customer revenue is\n                    generated by the franchisees. A receivable is recognized for an estimate of the unreported royalty\n                    fees, which are reported and remitted to us in arrears.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#164fa2;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Costs\n                    to Obtain a Contract With a Customer'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n                    capitalize the incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer, primarily commissions, as\n                    contract assets and recognize the expense on a straight-line basis over a weighted average expected\n                    customer relationship period. Capitalized commissions are classified as current or noncurrent based\n                    on the timing of when we expect to recognize the expense. Prior to November 1, 2018, such\n                    incremental costs were expensed as incurred.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#164fa2;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:700;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Contract\n                    Balances'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'The\n                    timing of revenue recognition, billings, and cash collections results in contract assets and\n                    contract liabilities, as further explained below. The timing of revenue recognition may differ from\n                    the timing of invoicing to customers. If a contract includes a cancellation clause that allows for\n                    the termination of the contract by either party without a substantive penalty, the contract term is\n                    limited to the termination notice period.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Contract\n                    assets primarily consist of billed trade receivables, unbilled trade receivables, and costs incurred\n                    in excess of amounts billed. Billed and unbilled trade receivables represent amounts from work\n                    completed in which we have an unconditional right to bill our customer. Costs incurred in excess of\n                    amounts billed typically arise when the revenue recognized on projects exceeds the amount billed to\n                    the customer. These amounts are transferred to billed'}}]}}, {'@id': 'ic99dc513144a44ecab8952399b09f3cb', '@continuedAt': 'ibc3fb2c81af44ab88d73875e64d7fe99', 'ix:continuation': {'@id': 'i2e6493923f70493a8cebd5acc754debb', 'div': [{'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'trade\n                    receivables when the rights become unconditional. Deferred tax assets and liabilities\n                    are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to temporary differences between the\n                    financial statement carrying amount of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax\n                    bases. We measure deferred tax assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates expected to be applied\n                    to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered.\n                    Deferred tax assets are reviewed for recoverability on a quarterly basis. ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Leases\n                    (Topic 842): Codification Improvements'}]}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Topic\n                    842 replaced existing lease accounting guidance and was intended to provide enhanced transparency\n                    and comparability by requiring lessees to record most leases on the balance sheet. Under Topic 842,\n                    lessees are required to record on the balance sheet ROU assets (the right to use an underlying asset\n                    for the lease term) and the corresponding lease liabilities (the obligation to make lease payments\n                    arising from the lease). This guidance requires us to continue classifying leases as either\n                    operating or financing, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the\n                    Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive (Loss) Income. In addition, this new standard requires\n                    enhanced disclosures surrounding the amount, timing, and uncertainty of cash flows arising from\n                    leasing arrangements.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'We\n                    adopted Topic 842 on November 1, 2019 on a modified retrospective basis using the optional\n                    transition method permitted under ASU 2018-11 and have used this effective date as the initial\n                    application date. Comparative prior period Financial Statements have not been restated and continue\n                    to be reported under the accounting standards in effect for those prior periods presented.'}}, {'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:36pt', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'Upon\n                    adoption, we elected the package of transition practical expedients that allowed us to carry forward\n                    prior conclusions related to: (i) whether any expired or existing contracts are or contain leases;\n                    (ii) the lease classification for any expired or existing leases; and (iii) initial direct costs for\n                    existing leases. Additionally, we elected the practical expedient of not separating lease components\n                    from non-lease components for all asset classes. We also made an accounting policy election to not\n                    record ROU assets or lease liabilities for leases with an'}}]}]}, {'@id': 'i92512299192f4268869a569040e6ce2f', '@continuedAt': 'i1970c4b1c66d4a9ca96205145e4294fa', 'ix:continuation': {'@id': 'i060cb8b1b5594f5fa43b7ad077c88161', '@continuedAt': 'i87e6bca01e344621bcd81f8ad3ec7ac8', 'div': [{'@style': 'margin-top:9pt;text-align:justify', 'span': {'@style': ""color:#000000;font-family:'Arial',sans-serif;font-size:10pt;font-weight:400;line-height:120%"", '#text': 'initial\n                    term of 12 months or less and will recognize payments for such leases in our Consolidated Statements\n                    of Comprehensive (Loss) Income on a straight-line basis over the lease term. The Lease Modification Q&A provides entities with the option to\n                    elect to account for lease concessions as though the enforceable rights and obligations existed in\n                    the original lease when the total cash flows resulting from the modified lease are substantially\n                    similar to the cash flows in the original lease. We have elected this practical expedient for\n                    Pandemic-related rent concessions, primarily rent deferrals or rent abatements, and we have elected\n                    not to remeasure the related lease liability and ROU asset for those leases. These concessions will\n                    be recognized as a reduction of rent expense in the month they occur. This election will continue\n                    while these concessions are in effect. Under Topic 326, an\n                    organization is required to measure all expected credit losses for financial assets held at the\n                    reporting date based on historical experience, current conditions, and reasonable and supportable\n                    forecasts that affect the collectability of the reported financial assets.
